cards.front: What does 'direct coupling' mean in a multi-stage amplifier?
cards.back: No coupling capacitor between stages — the DC collector voltage of one stage directly biases the base of the next stage.

cards.front: What transistor types are used in this lab's two-stage amplifier, and why?
cards.back: Q1 = BC549 (NPN), Q2 = BC556 (PNP). The complementary pair provides thermal stability because temperature drifts partially cancel.

cards.front: What is the key bias relationship in the direct-coupled amplifier?
cards.back: VC1 = VB2 — the collector voltage of Q1 equals the base voltage of Q2.

cards.front: Why does direct coupling maintain gain at low frequencies?
cards.back: No coupling capacitor to create a high-pass filter — gain is flat down to DC.

cards.front: What are the 12 values in the E12 resistor series (per decade)?
How does temperature increase affect IC in an NPN transistor?
cards.back: IC increases due to: (1) ICBO roughly doubles per 10°C, and (2) VBE decreases ~2mV/°C, both increasing IC.

cards.front: How do NPN-PNP complementary pairs achieve thermal stability?
cards.back: Temperature rise → IC1↑ → VC1↓ → VB2↓ → IC2↓ for the PNP. The opposing drift provides inherent negative feedback.

cards.front: What is hoe for the BC549, and what does it represent physically?
cards.back: hoe = 18μS = 1/56kΩ. It's the output admittance — the reciprocal of the output resistance of the transistor in common-emitter configuration.

cards.front: When can you safely ignore a parallel resistor in circuit analysis?
cards.back: When it is ≥10× the other (the '10× rule'). The parallel combination will be within ~10% of the smaller value.

cards.front: How many bias circuits does the direct-coupled two-stage amplifier need?
cards.back: Just one — the Ra/Rb voltage divider sets VB1, which cascades through the entire circuit to set both Q-points.

cards.front: What is the maximum power dissipation for both BC549 and BC556?
cards.back: 500 mW at Ta = 25°C. The operating point must satisfy VCE × IC < 500 mW.
